Benjamin Ehrenberg.title: Quantifying Value-Adds Methodology
Benjamin Ehrenberg.description: Repeatable framework for tracking gratuitous services with dollar figures (frequent setups, escort avoidance, out-of-scope work)
Benjamin Ehrenberg.context: At Lockheed Martin, Ben needed to demonstrate value beyond base contract scope. The challenge: clients see routine service execution as 'just doing your job,' not as added value. Ben created a systematic framework to track and quantify all gratuitous services with actual dollar figures - things like frequent last-minute setups, escort avoidance, and out-of-scope work that other vendors would charge for. This transforms client perception from 'meeting expectations' to 'delivering measurable partnership value.' Leadership explicitly challenged Ben to implement this in 2026 as it provides powerful retention ammunition during renewals by showing documented cost avoidance.
Benjamin Ehrenberg.impact: Demonstrates true partnership value; provides retention ammunition during renewals

Mark Schlerf.title: Gap Analysis as Strategic Opportunity Framework

Mark Schlerf.context: When CBRE asked Mark to conduct a gap analysis at Lam Research comparing contract language to actual performance across sites, it could have been a landmine - exposing service deficiencies and creating ammunition for price reduction or termination. Instead, Mark strategically reframed it as an opportunity identification exercise. He showed 'what is different by location' and presented the gaps as investment opportunities for the client to fund scope improvements. This turned a potential liability into a value conversation, positioning SBM as a strategic partner rather than a vendor under scrutiny. Nick Viskovich praised this approach as a masterclass in strategic thinking.
Mark Schlerf.impact: Converted potential liability into client investment in scope improvements

This governance model has strengthened the IFM relationship to the point where renewals happen off-market without competitive bidding. Nick Viskovich noted this as a replicable best practice that creates predictability and reduces client anxiety while positioning SBM as an indispensable strategic partner rather than a transactional vendor.
Mark Schlerf.impact: Strengthened IFM relationships; secured off-market renewals
Mark Schlerf.leadership_endorsement: Nick Viskovich noted as strong governance model

Stuart took a radically different approach for NVIDIA's April 2026 renewal: he planned throughout ALL of 2025, implementing consistent reinvestment practices as an operating rhythm rather than a 'renewal push.' This means tiered wage increases, equipment upgrades, and governance improvements happened steadily all year. The result: NVIDIA positioned to renew early in February (2 months ahead), avoided RFP risk, and is now going on year 9 with SBM (3rd consecutive renewal). Leadership gave this approach 5/5 scores and cited it as a best practice for de-risking renewals and building genuine partnerships.

Stuart Kelloff.title: Tiered Wage Rate Structure / Frontline Reinvestment

Stuart Kelloff.context: For NVIDIA's renewal, Stuart worked with the client to create a tiered wage rate structure built from the ground up - differentiating starting employees from experienced staff. Instead of taking margin to the bottom line or reducing client costs, Stuart reinvested the savings back into the frontline team through wage increases and career progression pathways. NVIDIA saw this as partnership behavior rather than profit extraction. The client explicitly wanted this reinvestment approach as part of the renewal strategy. Nick Viskovich gave this 5/5 for value-add, noting it improves retention, reduces training costs, and positions SBM as an employer of choice.

This creates a predictable rhythm where issues surface early and get resolved before they escalate. It also demonstrates transparency and partnership commitment that monthly reviews can't match. Leadership noted this as a governance best practice that reduces client complaints by 60%+, strengthens partnership perception, and serves as an early warning system. The discipline of weekly reviews forces operational excellence and eliminates the 'hoping problems go away' trap.
Stuart Kelloff.impact: Proactive issue identification; strengthened trust; reduced surprises
Stuart Kelloff.leadership_endorsement: Leadership noted as governance best practice

Jacqueline Maravilla.title: Non-Routine to ATB Budget Conversion

Deep analysis revealed non-routine work orders (urgent cleanings, emergency responses, GMP area shutdowns) were consuming SOW headcount budget but weren't being billed separately - classic scope creep. She met directly with the Alonza customer and proposed moving all non-routine work to above-the-base billing. The client agreed, generating $6K/month in sustained additional revenue while freeing up SOW headcount for actual routine work. This systematic approach to scope management turned the account from red to green and protected margins without sacrificing service quality. Nick Viskovich and Dan Hartman praised this as a replicable methodology for identifying hidden revenue.
Jacqueline Maravilla.impact: $6k/month sustained additional revenue; freed up SOW headcount for routine work; resolved budget red status

Giselle Langelier.title: Educating Client on Contract Language to Limit Credits/Scope Creep

Giselle Langelier.context: Medtronic contract has rate card with positions/hours and clause allowing credit requests for hours not worked. As long as SBM hits 90% of planned hours, client doesn't invoke clause. Small sites (like Irvine bell) notice absences and request credits incorrectly. Example: client asked for 25% credit for 1 of 4 people missing. Giselle educated: 'It doesn't work that way - it's by position (different hourly rates), and you have to account for OT from others covering the gap.' Supervisor position = $30/hr fully burdened, cleaner = $22/hr. Credit calculated by missing position rate minus OT from coverage. Giselle navigated this by: (1) maintaining transparency with hours reports, (2) educating clients on contract language, (3) staying above 90% threshold, and (4) leveraging strong relationships at most sites so clients don't invoke clause. This prevents margin erosion from improper credit requests while maintaining service quality.

Keith Deuber.title: Relationship Campaign - Operations Team Focus Over Category Team

But what we didn't have in focus was the operations teams. The operations teams, even though they do not single-handedly assign the work, they do have heavy influence throughout the year of losing sites, winning sites as well as coming up in the 2027 or 2026 RFP.' Target roles: 'We started to meet with the SPMs, the RPMs, as well as the POLs or the procurement operation leaders, and those three roles are really what determines success at a site. A POR can come in, they can stamp of approval or they can put you on a PIP.' Implementation: 'Throughout the year, beginning of the year and then Dustin obviously came on midway through the year and it kind of went into hyperdrive.' Result: 'We shifted our focus throughout 2025 to focus on the procurement operations and getting in front of them, having constant communication and really changing the perspective of Amazon about SBM starting with that group because they have the most I would say influence when it comes to category.'

Keith Deuber.title: Strategic Operations Governance - Daily 15-Min Touchbases During Peak
Keith Deuber.description: Implemented Teams regional chats for real-time communication; established 15-minute daily touchbases during peak (started one month before); enabled shift-by-shift responsiveness; achieved zero escalations, 93.3% average, zero PIPs during peak
Keith Deuber.context: Amazon's unique risk: 'Amazon is different from other accounts. This is not an account that is, you know, hey, you have a year contract, three-year contract, we'll review it at the end of the contract. This is truly you fail two months in a row, you could potentially be on a pip. We're fending off a pip. You fail three in a row, you could potentially be kicked out of the site. So the typical standard on SBM internal communications just didn't work because it's a week to week contract, almost a shift by shift. You could drop a ball on a shift, next you know you're getting escalations.' Solution: '(1) Utilizing teams and setting up individual region by region teams chats to ensure that we're communicating real time. (2) During peak, starting about a month before peak, we set up 15 minute touch bases every single day with the teams, with the site managers, the regional, the area managers, just to make sure that we're communicating who was on site, where are the challenges, where are the gaps, when's the audit, what are the challenges of that week or that day?' Peak results: 'That truly I think was a driver into having 0 escalations during peak averaging at 93.3, which is significantly higher than we averaged during the peak prior and we were the only company that had zero sites on PIP throughout Peak, which is what's called out through our supplier Peak debrief with Marco Rosano.' This demonstrates Keith's understanding that Amazon requires fundamentally different communication cadence than typical SBM accounts.
Keith Deuber.impact: Zero escalations during peak; 93.3% average (significantly higher than prior peak); only company with zero PIPs; real-time shift-level responsiveness
Keith Deuber.leadership_endorsement: Marco Rosano called out SBM as only company with zero PIPs during supplier peak debrief

Keith Deuber.title: BI Dashboard Proof of Concept - Predictive Site Failure Analysis

Keith Deuber.context: Challenge: 'Amazon provides us with the weekly scorecard and then we also have to implement and send in a KPI document detailing out hours utilization, any service credits, staffing and such like that. What we were struggling with at the beginning of the year was digesting and actioning on those items, finding the key indicators to a site or trending to a site that is failing or catching it before it starts to have an escalation.' Solution: 'We created a BI dashboard with the innovations team that really allows us internally to track and trend and make predictive analysis on where a site's trending. Is it going to fail? What are the week over week fail trends and really put it on to a dashboard that allows us to make data-driven decisions to be able to sustain high operations.' This demonstrates Keith's strategic thinking to move from reactive to predictive operations management.
Keith Deuber.impact: Predictive site failure analysis; proactive intervention before escalations; data-driven decisions; week-over-week trend identification
Keith Deuber.leadership_endorsement: Innovation team collaboration; moves from reactive to predictive operations

Keith Deuber.title: Four Equipment-Driven Efficiencies for Tight Amazon Labor Model
Keith Deuber.description: Implemented steam cleaners (bathroom grout), portable power supplies (6-hour workstation cleaning during breaks), stick vacuums (45-min break room requirement), blowers (under-rack cleaning 12-15 racks/day vs 3); delivered labor savings in extremely tight Amazon environment
Keith Deuber.context: Labor pressure: 'Amazon has been extremely tight and to save an hour here, an hour there from an efficiency standpoint helps us a lot.' Four innovations: (1) Steam cleaners for bathroom grout, (2) Portable supplies for workstation cleanings - 'Power pack that runs for about 6 hours that you can take and plug stuff into. So it's more maneuverable and efficient when it comes to cleaning. Specifically with Amazon, you have to clean the workstation during peak. Only time you can do that. Think about an AR sort 4 floors, about 500 workstations. You have their breaks. You have two or three half hour to an hour break that you can clean the workstations. So that has significantly helped upkeep throughout peak and then it's going to help outside of peak with the dark times, 5:00 to 7:00 AM, PM, we're able to get more people up there. We don't have to use cords,' (3) Stick vacuum for break rooms - 'Break rooms according to the fail criteria and according to scope of work, it has to be fully cleaned within 45 minutes post break. We were either sweeping or taking a quarter vacuum and vacuuming, whereas with the stick vacs which are great for break rooms, it created the efficiency and it really helped us across the board hit that 45 minute post break cleaning deadline,' (4) Blowers for rack cleanings - 'Previously we were not cleaning the under racks throughout the month it was two-month, three month turn around... Getting blowers, implementing blowers rather than using a dust mop underneath the racking significantly helped the efficiency. Instead of getting 3 racks done, we're getting 12 to 15 racks done a day, which was creating that monthly cadence.' Outcome: 'Increased speed, improved quality and reduce the manual effort creating that efficiency.'
Keith Deuber.impact: 500 workstations cleanable during breaks; 45-min break room deadline achieved; 12-15 racks/day vs 3 (4-5x improvement); under-rack failures eliminated (only HDR5 in 6 months); labor hours saved
Keith Deuber.leadership_endorsement: Delivered efficiency in Amazon's tight labor environment; multiple equipment innovations scaled

Keith Deuber.title: Revamped TQM Process - Proactive Site Assessment Before Client Identifies Gaps
Keith Deuber.description: Revamped old TQM process tailored to Amazon; monthly assessments checking operations, building condition, and processes; account team owns, R&D executes; prevents reactive firefighting when high-performing sites suddenly face PIPs
Keith Deuber.context: Problem identified: 'We have sites that are doing really well, 95 plus for months on end and then next thing you know the Amazon changes in SPM, RPM walks the site, VP comes in, does a visit and then we're fending off a pip. What this is stemming from is that once we see a site that's scoring well, we take our foot off the pedal. Oh, it's perfectly fine. It's good. We don't need to worry about it. And then we're playing catch up and being reactive.' Solution: 'We've revamped the TQM process and we've made it tailored to Amazon to check not only operation or the building condition, but to also make sure we have all of our processes in place. As we go forward in this presentation, you'll see the processes that we're going to be implementing. It is an assessment of everything like the old TQM and it's going to be done on a monthly basis. The account team's going to own the process, the R&D team is going to execute the process and this will significantly help us identify gaps prior to an RPM VP identifying the gaps and then calling us out on them. So we're going to execute that and roll that out Q1 this year.' Keith's confidence: 'I'm very confident on this cause the old TQM process worked now. It's just I don't think we did it enough and I think there was too many lines on it. So this is a scaled down version identified and really strategically implemented.'
Keith Deuber.impact: Proactive gap identification before client; prevents PIP surprises; monthly cadence prevents complacency; account team ownership with R&D execution
Keith Deuber.leadership_endorsement: Valarie: 'You'll pilot this and then you'll let us know. Specifically me, you'll let me know... this will work'

Tiffany Purifoy.title: Periodic Task Calendar - Eliminated Client Complaints at TRP Colorado

Tiffany Purifoy.title: Mother's Room & Fitness Center Process - Prevented Repeat Privacy Incidents
Tiffany Purifoy.description: Implemented new entry process after two incidents at TRP (mother's room, fitness center); knock, wait 10 seconds, knock again, then enter even if IT light shows unoccupied; zero incidents since implementation; client appreciative
Tiffany Purifoy.context: Incidents: 'We've had two pretty important issues that occurred and one of them was an SBM entering a space. It was one of them was a mother's room. Another incident was a fitness center. Though I'm not sure if everyone's familiar with, there are lights on the door that let you know if it was occupied or not. In both incidences the IT stated that it was unoccupied. SBM employee knocked. There was no response. Employee entered to someone in the space.' Solution: 'Working directly with JLL and T. Rowe Price, we implemented a new process. Jacob Reed.title: Taping Team Evolution - 1.2M Sq Ft + Engineering Integration + Cyber Cab Showcase
Jacob Reed.description: Taping team evolved from EHS one-off support to standalone 'golden child' program integrated with Tesla engineering; laid 1.2M sq ft of tape in 2025; responsible for all visible tape designs in Cyber Cab showcase unveils
Jacob Reed.context: Evolution: 'The taping team has been a huge win for us. It was a program that felt like kind of a one-off and more of a hey, let's just help the customer at this point. But now the taping team has turned into kind of their own standalone golden child of Tesla.' Scale: 'This year they laid over 1.2 million square feet of tape, which is crazy to think about.' Integration: 'Now they're starting to get involved with even some of the engineering teams. It used to just be kind of an EHS one-off and now we're actually integrating into Tesla's team.' Showcase impact: 'Right now they're supporting the Cyber Cab. Whenever you do see pictures or layouts or just overall reviews of the Cyber Cab spaces, these things open up and the product unveils all the tape that you see, all the really nice designs, the real crisp look and avenues, those are all the SBM taping teams.'
Jacob Reed.impact: 1.2M sq ft tape laid annually; evolved from one-off to standalone program; engineering team integration (beyond EHS); Cyber Cab showcase visibility; brand elevation
Jacob Reed.leadership_endorsement: Tesla's 'golden child' program; engineering integration demonstrates trust

Jacob Reed.title: Proactive Maintenance Approach - $6K Sink to $120 Fixture Root Cause Analysis
Jacob Reed.description: Maintenance team shifted from reactive ticket chasing to proactive root cause analysis; example: instead of replacing $6K sink, identified calcium buildup and replaced $120 fixture; Tesla now requesting SBM partnership on broader facilities maintenance
Jacob Reed.context: Reactive past: 'For the longest time we've been really reactive and we kind of just taking things and kind of like how do we get to the next ticket. I think Edgar and his team are really taking that to be more of a proactive approach instead of just throwing, allowing us to throw money at it and just say the sink is broken, just buy a new one. It costs like $6,000 for the sink.' Proactive approach: 'Edgar and his team actually took a second to say, hey, what do we find on the root of the problem? They remove the sink and find out there's just calcium buildup or inadequate pieces that people just kind of threw together because there was a deadline to get these areas turn over. Now we're actually bringing these permanent solutions that are actually instead of a $6,000 sink, it's replacing $120 fixture.' Client response: 'Now we're really getting our foothold on there where it's even getting to the part where they're like, hey, can you guys partner with facilities? What does it look like to give SBM more of the visual, more of the eye-opening to the maintenance world that goes into keeping the factory up and running.' Impact: 'It really just helps elevate us to where we're walking step with Tesla where it's how do we keep SBM growing with us.'
Jacob Reed.impact: Massive cost savings via root cause analysis ($120 vs $6K example); Tesla requesting facilities partnership expansion; elevated from 'vendor to the side' to strategic partner; Edgar leadership recognized
Jacob Reed.leadership_endorsement: Tesla requesting expansion of SBM maintenance role; walking step with client

Jacob Reed.title: Flood Support Process - $200K Savings + 4 Hours to 45 Minutes Response
Jacob Reed.description: Developed systematic flood response process reducing response time from 4 hours to 45 minutes; saved Tesla $200K in 2025 by eliminating need for subcontractors; tracking and quantifying value monthly
Jacob Reed.context: Problem: 'With the amount of adjustments and demand that Tesla's doing of like moving the factory around daily, monthly, there's always someone that's hitting either a pipe or hitting fire sprinklers, releasing hundreds of thousands of gallons of water. It became just an ordeal where production is down. Everybody's just waiting. The cars won't move because there's water in the way.' Old process: 'In the past it's taken us about four hours to get all this water kind of in once to center, get it all taken care of, get it all soaked up and moved on.' New process: 'Now where it's down to like 45 minutes to an hour, hour at the max. There's a process, there's a direction and there's guidance from our team. Our team looks like they're supposed to be there. People get excited where they're like SBM's here, they're going to take care of this water. We can keep moving from production because everybody's getting hounded in the background of like, why aren't these cars being made?' Value quantification: 'We were happy to announce to them that we saved them about $200K in savings. It wasn't necessarily built into our scope when we first started. We were just there for more of a residual water cleanup to where we took on the actual flooding in itself. They're not having to bring out any subvendors.' Tracking: 'We're able to give them that like a solid number. Now we're tracking that daily, monthly for them to be able to see that we are bringing that value add.'
Jacob Reed.impact: $200K annual savings quantified; 75% time reduction (4 hours → 45 min); eliminated subcontractor delays (4-24 hour wait); production uptime protected; sticky service enhancement
Jacob Reed.leadership_endorsement: John Mann requested documentation for scaling; Valarie emphasized huge win

Jacob Reed.title: Cost Savings Strategy Shift - Budget Alignment vs Egregious Demands
Jacob Reed.description: Shifted narrative from client-demanded cost savings ($600K+/month expectations) to proactive budget alignment with factory schedules; delivered $250K in holiday/shutdown savings while protecting operational integrity
Jacob Reed.context: Old approach problem: 'The real goal internally for me is getting away from planning Tesla a lot of these cost savings. When we first started the account it was like how can we get SBM to give us more than $600,000 a month back in cost savings? It was like an expectation for you guys to just give us a giant amount of money back. It became like a nightmare trying to move things around.' New approach: 'I really wanted to show them the overall leader budget, being able to tell them these are necessities that we need. We're not over asking. We're not trying to take advantage. It was more or less aligning with them. We'll give you the cost savings that structure with how the factory operates, IE like holidays and factory shutdowns. We're able to go in there, produce some savings for them and say like, you guys are down, we see that we're not going to overstaff for a factory that's dead.' Results: 'Aligning with them on their schedules, kind of integrating into what Tesla's doing and kind of getting ahead of it instead of asking the customer how much do you need to save. It's more or less like, hey, what does the schedule looks like? Oh great, with that kind of reductions I can save you guys as much money. That one also came out to about $250K with the reduction there. Those were like just for major holidays, Christmas, Thanksgiving, 4th of July, MLK Day and Veteran's Day.' Philosophy: 'It's a really good way to just not allow them to push us around and kind of put our foot down and say, hey, we're going to move in the right direction of the budgets that we asked for are lean because they reflect exactly what we need and any kind of cost savings we'll be more than happy to give back to you, but those are justified and not like being over budgeted.'
Jacob Reed.impact: $250K holiday/shutdown savings delivered; eliminated $600K+ egregious demands; established budget integrity; proactive scheduling alignment; protected operational necessities
Jacob Reed.leadership_endorsement: Shifted power dynamic; sustainable cost savings model vs unsustainable demands

Jacob Reed.title: Work Ticketing System Adoption - Ranked #1 of 6 Programs
Jacob Reed.description: Adopted Tesla's internally-built 'Work' ticketing system (AI-driven social media style); janitorial team ranked #1 out of 6 site programs for feedback scores, ticket closure time, and solution quality
Jacob Reed.context: System context: 'The biggest one here was a test that came out with their big unveil of Work. It's their internal ticketing system. It's something that they actually build up from the ground up and something that they're very nervous to unveil because it really puts the POC in the spotlight. The Tesla team said, hey, we're doing a really great job with ForoInsight, but let's let's help can kind of keep that seam lead there.' Functionality: 'It's very much like AI would say kind of a social media type thing where people put in these requests and then the managers on site will kind of walk the customer through it, whether we can support them, if it's outside of our scope and it needs to go somewhere else. It's a way for people to get feedback on how the janitorial team is doing, and overall it's just like a nice combination of like a community where these problems can be taken care of behind scenes instead of it being exploded on email, on the Microsoft Teams.' Hesitation overcome: 'There was a lot of hesitation where Tesla didn't feel like the SBM team couldn't get a hang of it or they can do it. Or it was too much of a demand. It was nice to be able to tell the customer like, hey, let us do our thing. You brought us here. We're tech savvy. We already have the ForoInsight platform, the team already knows how to get into it, show them, report it.' Results: 'We were pleased to announce that we actually the janitorial team was actually ranked number one out of the six different programs that are on site. Ranking mean like a better score just in terms of like overall feedback from Tesla employees and overall just the way we're closing tickets at a certain time and the quality that we're bringing in the solutions. We're not just hard stopping. We're actually giving avenues of ways to we can't help you directly, but this person can help or this team can help.'
Jacob Reed.impact: Ranked #1 of 6 site programs; overcame client skepticism about SBM tech capability; leveraged ForoInsight experience; ticket quality and closure time excellence; solution-oriented responses
Jacob Reed.leadership_endorsement: Tesla's nervous unveil succeeded with SBM; #1 ranking validates tech-savvy team

Jacob Reed.title: Monthly Equipment Training Program - Vendor-Led Hands-On with Public Documentation
Jacob Reed.description: Implemented monthly public equipment training sessions with vendor partnerships (Tenant, Kaivac); hands-on experience, documented, customer-invited; improved machine longevity and discovered optimization features
Jacob Reed.context: Problem: 'Constant machines being down. Wear and tear on these machines are being used 24/7. Tesla felt like it was mainly like a negligence or not being used properly. I don't think it was negligence. I think it's just the wear and tear of a constant machine.' Solution: 'To get ahead of it, we actually set up monthly trainings. These are actually publicly open. We do a lot of hands on experience, hands on training with the employees. We allow the customer to come out, we document them, we go through all these little training seminars. We bring out vendors to come and show them like Tenant will come out and do a hands on. So you get the expertise from a Tenant supplier and now we're on a monthly schedule now.' Results: 'The customer pops in. You love seeing it and our team is really starting to one, show the longevity of the machines, but two, actually starting to find those tricks and kind of nice little adds to those machines that maybe you wouldn't notice right off the bat. We're actually being able to have our floor techs and have our employees be those master experts for the machines that are on site.'
Jacob Reed.impact: Monthly training cadence established; vendor partnerships (Tenant, Kaivac) for expertise; customer invited and attending; improved equipment longevity; discovered optimization features; team mastery
Jacob Reed.leadership_endorsement: Addressed Tesla's negligence concerns proactively; vendor partnerships for training

Jacob Reed.title: Single Vendor Strategy - Cross-Departmental Communication Expansion
Jacob Reed.description: Broke down Tesla's workplace-only communication barriers; now supporting construction teams (with Michael's help), positioning SBM as singular vendor for all facility needs vs multiple vendors/RFPs
Jacob Reed.context: Old barriers: 'As the growth kind of spurs and takes off, a lot of things we found in face was, you know, it was a lot of like, hey, don't talk to these people or don't talk to these teams. You're with workplace only. We don't like to communicate with these other people. You know, we're very tight knit with our team.' Breakthrough: 'We've really taken off to where we're starting to help construction teams. Michael's been a huge help with being able to confirm those handshakes where SBM's actually started to jump into these so different scopes and now people are starting to say like oh you know this is really great to have this one singular vendor.' Vision: 'That's kind of the overall goal of being here with them with the program. I want to be that one singular vendor where Tesla doesn't have to do RFPs or go out for quotes or just say I need three different vendors. They just say hey SBM, what do you need to be able to scale this so you can continue to support us as best as you can?'
Jacob Reed.impact: Broke workplace-only silo; construction team support added; singular vendor positioning; eliminated RFP dependency for expansions; client convenience and trust
Jacob Reed.leadership_endorsement: Valarie recognized 'sticky' positioning; single vendor goal aligns with SBM growth strategy
